thread.title: Oil prices fall on strong dollar, Brent near one-month low

title: Oil prices fall on strong dollar, Brent near one-month low
text:
February 5, 2018 / 12:55 AM / Updated 32 minutes ago Oil prices fall on strong dollar, Brent near one-month low Reuters Staff 2 Min Read 
TOKYO (Reuters) - Oil prices on Monday extended declines from the end of last week on the back of a stronger dollar, with Brent crude falling to its lowest in nearly a month. 
Other markets dropped as investors   years, fuelling   
That drove the greenback higher, which puts pressure on oil as the commodity is priced in dollars. 
Brent LCOc1 was down 75 cents, or 1.1 percent, at $67.83 a barrel at 0033 GMT, after falling 1.5 percent on Friday. 
U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude CLc1 declined 66 cents to $64.79, after dropping 0.5 percent in the previous session. 
An index of the dollar against a basket of currencies .DXY rose to as high as around 89.38, approaching peaks reached on Friday, after the report showed U.S. jobs growth surged in January and wages rose, clocking up their biggest annual gain in more than 8-1/2 years. 
Rising U.S. oil production is also pushing down prices, undermining attempts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) to support prices. 
Data from the U.S. government last week showed that output climbed above 10 million barrels per day in November for the first time since 1970, as shale drillers expanded operations after gains in oil prices last year. Reporting by Aaron SheldrickEditing by Joseph Radford
